Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Computational investigations on the HO<sub>2</sub> + CHBr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> reaction: mechanisms, products, and atmospheric implications.

AbstractText: Using quantum chemistry methods, mechanisms and products of the CHBr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> reaction in the atmosphere were investigated theoretically. Computational result indicates that the dominant product is CHBr<sub>2</sub>OOH + O<sub>2</sub> formed on the triplet potential energy surface (PES). While CBr<sub>2</sub>O + OH + HO<sub>2</sub> produced on the singlet PES is subdominant to the overall reaction under the typical atmospheric condition below 300 K. Due to higher energy barriers surmounted, other products including CBr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, CBr<sub>2</sub>O + HO<sub>3</sub>H, CH<sub>2</sub>O + HO<sub>3</sub>Br, CHBrO + HO<sub>3</sub> + Br, and CHBr<sub>2</sub>OH + O<sub>3</sub> make minor contributions to the overall reaction. In the presence of OH radical, CHBr<sub>2</sub>OOH generates CHBr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> and CBr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O subsequently, which enters into new Br-cycle in the atmosphere. The substitution effect of alkyl group and halogens plays negligible roles to the dominant products in the RO<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> (X = H, CH<sub>3</sub>, CH<sub>2</sub>OH, CH<sub>2</sub>F, CH<sub>2</sub>Cl, CH<sub>2</sub>Br, CH<sub>2</sub>Cl, and CH<sub>2</sub>Br) reactions in the atmosphere.
